content:
Validator 4 is harder than the rest. And it can be problematic if it is hidden in the final puzzle.

I explain :

In the validator 4, you dno't have all the informations about the square 2 just by reading the digits. The problem is that is for all others squares, you can just read all the digits and you already know the square size with just max(bottom- top, right - left). But for this 2 squares, you can't do just that. You have to see that you don't have all the informations of the squares and "adjust" to find the final size. Dealing with the 


And i there's an additional problem. You say  "in order from the first one drawn to the last.". In the validator 3, how are we suppose to know that the square 2 is the first ?

So, I was just looking at this again, and I realized that my solution to the puzzle relies on being able to simply deduce the location of a single corner because of two obvious intersecting walls. My code would need to be somewhat more complicated to unravel something like this:

.11111111
.1......1
.1......1
.33333..1
.3...3221
.3...3..1
444..3..1
434333111
444......

Since only a single wall of the '2' square can be "seen", my code fails on this test case. Is this [obvious corner] constraint intended? Is it desired? Just wondering.

Really nice idea, I have some questions before I approve it:
- Can square of size 1 exists? If not maybe it could be good to precise the length min and max of squares
- Can square NOT overlap? something like
111.222
1.1.2.2
111.222
If yes, please precise which one should be printed first.
If not, please precise that it's not possible.

Thanks a lot, awesome idea
I added the stub generator. I'm not sure if the character . (the dot in the phrase "the content of the grid. '.' for an empty spot") should be wrapped between '' or not.

Seems a really cool idea, though from the wording in output it's not very obvious what the order should be (the description in the goal is fine though). Just a suggestion but maybe switch it to something like "The number and size of the square, separated by a space, in order from the first one drawn to the last"

Also with the first example, it'd possibly be better to set the square of 2s to first drawn just to show it's not from the smallest number to largest.

Thx ^^
updated !
Look the exemple...
2 ≤ size ≤ 5
In all my tests, at least one label is visible for each square...

Agreed. Validator 4 is definitely harder. However, I just wanted to point out that it is not as hard as it could be. You at least know two extents to the square, so you only need to vary size. You don't need to vary position to find where the square "lives".

In the example I gave, since only one side is known, you need to play with both the size and position of the square. I'm just saying that the solution that I coded works on Validator 4, but would not work on the example that I provided.
Having an harder example is not bad. But it should be also present in a IDE test case.
Oh. I'm sorry. I mistook your comment as a reply to my comment above. I agree with you. It makes sense to introduce new complexity in the test cases, rather than in the validators.
Ok... Exemple 4 harder now !

Magus, I don't see the problem with the Validator 3...
2 before 1 and 1 before 3

Magus... In Validator 3, perhaps you are missing the fact that square '2' must be a square, and so must take up 4 grid spots (2 x 2). There are only 2 grid spots visible, and so the other 2 must be under square '1'. Make sense? I agree with VilBoub. The test is correct as written.
in validator 4, is quare 4 printed before square 1?

'4' must be last because it is on top of the upper-right corner of '5', which is hiding parts of '3', which covers the lower-right corner of '1', which is overlapping the upper-left corner of '2'.

It all hangs together.

I think you misunderstand me. :-) In my example at least one label is visible for each square as well. However, in all of your tests, at least TWO sides of each square are visible. In the example I gave, one of the squares has only a single side visible.

I test your example in my  code... No problem for me :
2 4
1 8
3 5
4 3

Right. Which is why I mention it. It is possible to generate "less correct" code that still passes all of your tests. Your solution code is more complete than the code that I came up with, and yet my code still passes all of the current tests.

Like I said, you are welcome to ignore it. It's just fine. I really meant it just as an FYI.
In Validator 3, square label 2 has only one side visible too...
In Validator 3 the square with label 2 actually has 3 sides visible! (a corner belongs to two sides, not one)

It's not clear what size is referring to, size of each square? If so Validator 4 has square of size 10 for example.

Also you didn't answer the overlap part of the question

Also this part in output:
"The number and size if the square" you should put "size" and "number" in yellow and use another term for number to not mistake it for "nb", for example "label" could fit more, and then you could change the Goal statement to explain that each square is represented by a label "L" ranging from 1 to 9.

Oups !
Updated : 2 ≤ size ≤ 10

And they are no confusion possible for the order of the squares...
